segment.source: This article describes how Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can use the Credential Locker to securely store and retrieve user credentials, and roam them between devices with the user's Microsoft account.
segment.target: This article describes how Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can use the Credential Locker to securely store and retrieve user credentials, and roam them between devices with the user's Microsoft account.

segment.source: For example, you have an app that connects to a service to access protected resources such as media files, or social networking.
segment.target: For example, you have an app that connects to a service to access protected resources such as media files, or social networking.

segment.source: Your service requires login information for each user.
segment.target: Your service requires login information for each user.

segment.source: You’ve built UI into your app that gets the username and password for the user, which is then used to log the user into the service.
segment.target: You’ve built UI into your app that gets the username and password for the user, which is then used to log the user into the service.

segment.source: Using the Credential Locker API, you can store the username and password for your user and easily retrieve them and log the user in automatically the next time they open your app, regardless of what device they're on.
segment.target: Using the Credential Locker API, you can store the username and password for your user and easily retrieve them and log the user in automatically the next time they open your app, regardless of what device they're on.

segment.source: Credential locker works a little differently for domain accounts.
segment.target: Credential locker works a little differently for domain accounts.

segment.source: If there are credentials stored with your Microsoft account, and you associate that account with a domain account (such as the account that you use at work), your credentials will roam to that domain account.
segment.target: If there are credentials stored with your Microsoft account, and you associate that account with a domain account (such as the account that you use at work), your credentials will roam to that domain account.

segment.source: However, any new credentials added when signed on with the domain account won’t roam.
segment.target: However, any new credentials added when signed on with the domain account won’t roam.

segment.source: This ensures that private credentials for the domain aren’t exposed outside of the domain.
segment.target: This ensures that private credentials for the domain aren’t exposed outside of the domain.

segment.source: Storing user credentials
segment.target: Storing user credentials

segment.source: Obtain a reference to the Credential Locker using the PasswordVault object from the Windows.Security.Credentials namespace.
segment.target: Obtain a reference to the Credential Locker using the PasswordVault object from the Windows.Security.Credentials namespace.

segment.source: Create a PasswordCredential object that contains an identifier for your app, the username and the password, and pass that to the PasswordVault.Add method to add the credential to the locker.
segment.target: Create a PasswordCredential object that contains an identifier for your app, the username and the password, and pass that to the PasswordVault.Add method to add the credential to the locker.

segment.source: Retrieving user credentials
segment.target: Retrieving user credentials

segment.source: You have several options for retrieving user credentials from the Credential Locker after you have a reference to the PasswordVault object.
segment.target: You have several options for retrieving user credentials from the Credential Locker after you have a reference to the PasswordVault object.

segment.source: You can retrieve all the credentials the user has supplied for your app in the locker with the PasswordVault.RetrieveAll method.
segment.target: You can retrieve all the credentials the user has supplied for your app in the locker with the PasswordVault.RetrieveAll method.

segment.source: If you know the username for the stored credentials, you can retrieve all the credentials for that username with the PasswordVault.FindAllByUserName method.
segment.target: If you know the username for the stored credentials, you can retrieve all the credentials for that username with the PasswordVault.FindAllByUserName method.

segment.source: If you know the resource name for the stored credentials, you can retrieve all the credentials for that resource name with the PasswordVault.FindAllByResource method.
segment.target: If you know the resource name for the stored credentials, you can retrieve all the credentials for that resource name with the PasswordVault.FindAllByResource method.

segment.source: Finally, if you know both the username and the resource name for a credential, you can retrieve just that credential with the PasswordVault.Retrieve method.
segment.target: Finally, if you know both the username and the resource name for a credential, you can retrieve just that credential with the PasswordVault.Retrieve method.

segment.source: Let’s look at an example where we have stored the resource name globally in an app and we log the user on automatically if we find a credential for them.

segment.source: If we find multiple credentials for the same user, we ask the user to select a default credential to use when logging on.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: Only use the credential locker for passwords and not for larger data blobs.
segment.target: Only use the credential locker for passwords and not for larger data blobs.

segment.target: Save passwords in the credential locker only if the following criteria are met:
